dc:description:
*EXOC7* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive neurodevelopmental disorder with seizures and brain atrophy in 2020 (Coulter et al., 2020, PMID: 32103185). Partial loss-of-function variants in EXOC7 are associated with developmental brain disorders of variable severity characterized by developmental delay, seizures, brain atrophy, microcephaly, and infantile death. Given the spectrum of neurodevelopmental features observed, the gene is curated under “complex neurodevelopmental disorder” (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/MONDO_0100038).

Four variants (1 splice site mutation, 2 in-frame deletions, and 1 missense mutation) reported in four probands in one publication are included in this curation. All variants are predicted to yield hypomorphic alleles. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by a zebrafish animal model (Coulter et al., 2020, PMID: 32103185). 

In summary, there is moderate evidence supporting the relationship between EXCO7 and AR neurodevelopmental disorder with seizures and brain atrophy. This has not been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings. This classification was approved by the Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date June 20, 2023 (SOP Version 9).

evidence.dc:description: Zebrafish with homozygous loss of exoc7 showed head edema, microcephaly, and small eyes, as well as increased neuronal apoptosis in the developing telencephalon. These findings suggested that the microcephaly and brain atrophy in human with NEDSEBA results from loss of proliferating progenitor cells and postmitotic neurons, consistent with a neurodegenerative process.
evidence.rdfs:label: Coulter - Zebrafish Model

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded to 2.0 points as per this GCEP’s  scoring guidelines

Immunoblot of EXOC7 protein in cells with the patient’s variant showed reduced expression of EXOC7 compared to wild type, as well as disrupted splicing. While unconfirmed, the differential splicing which eliminates the expression of the exon 7 included isoform, suggests this variant is pathogenic by disrupting cortical development.

evidence.rdfs:label: Coulter - 1-01
evidence.detectionMethod: DNA was extracted from whole blood and homozygosity mapping and exome sequencing was performed. Sanger sequencing was used to confirm genotype from exome sequencing and determine segregation within the family.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: neonatal microencephaly, seizures, and arthrogryposis, microcephaly, thin cortex, extremely simplified gyral pattern, moderate ventriculomegaly, diminished and watery white matter, thin corpus callosum, thin optic nerves, absent basal ganglia,small thalami, large bilateral subdural hematomas, extremely thin cerebellar hemispheres, absent vermis, tiny brainstem with midline cleft (MRI)

evidence.rdfs:label: Coulter - IV-05
evidence.detectionMethod: DNA was extracted from whole blood and homozygosity mapping and exome sequencing was performed. Sanger sequencing to confirm genotype from exome sequencing and determine segregation within the family.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: seizures, intellectual disability, Mild/Moderate  developmental delay

evidence.dc:description: Per ID/A GCEP scoring guidelines, variants will be scored at a maximum of 2 pts

evidence.rdfs:label: Coulter - II-04
evidence.detectionMethod: DNA was extracted from whole blood and homozygosity mapping and exome sequencing was performed. Sanger sequencing confirmed genotype from exome sequencing and determine segregation within the family.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: 6 months, myoclonic and focal with versive head movement, severe developmental delay, mild hypertonia, Brain Imaging; central and cortical atrophy, especially temporal lobe

evidence.rdfs:label: Coulter-Family 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: neonatal microencephaly, seizures, and arthrogryposis, microcephaly, thin cortex, extremely simplified gyral pattern, moderate ventriculomegaly, diminished and watery white matter, thin corpus callosum, thin optic nerves, absent basal ganglia,small thalami, large bilateral subdural hematomas, extremely thin cerebellar hemispheres, absent vermis, tiny brainstem with midline cleft (MRI)

evidence.rdfs:label: Coulter - Family 3

member.rdfs:label: Coulter - III-03
member.detectionMethod: DNA was extracted from whole blood and homozygosity mapping and exome sequencing was performed. Sanger sequencing to confirm genotype from exome sequencing and determine segregation within the family.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Mild retrognathism, Fetal ultrasound: microcephaly, brainstem and cerebellar hypoplasia, Neuropathological examination: microcephaly (biparietal diameter 60 mm, below 3rd percentile), pronounced hypoplasia of the posterior fossa, cerebellum-brainstem weight and  transverse cerebellar diameter (25 mm) below the 3rd percentile. The cerebellum and brainstem appeared macroscopically hypoplastic with a reduced foliation of the vermis.  Microscopic examination of the cerebellum showed neuronal heterotopia and fragmented cerebellar dentate nuclei.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Mild retrognathism, Fetal ultrasound: microcephaly, brainstem and cerebellar hypoplasia, Neuropathological examination: microcephaly (biparietal diameter 60 mm, below 3rd percentile), pronounced hypoplasia of the posterior fossa, cerebellum-brainstem weight and  transverse cerebellar diameter (25 mm) below the 3rd percentile. The cerebellum and brainstem appeared macroscopically hypoplastic with a reduced foliation of the vermis.  Microscopic examination of the cerebellum showed neuronal heterotopia and fragmented cerebellar dentate nuclei.

evidence.rdfs:label: Coulter - Family 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: 6 months, myoclonic and focal with versive head movement, severe developmental delay, mild hypertonia, Brain Imaging; central and cortical atrophy, especially temporal lobe

evidence.dc:description: This is an autosomal recessive condition affecting 3 individuals in family 4.
evidence.rdfs:label: Coulter - Family 4
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: seizures, intellectual disability, Mild/Moderate  developmental delay, brain atrophy
